skill.name: technical-decision-record
skill.description: Use when making technical decisions, choosing technologies, or documenting architectural choices. Creates ADRs (Architecture Decision Records).
skill.summary: Use when making technical decisions, choosing technologies, or documenting architectural choices. Cr...
skill.author: ChaiWithJai

security_audit.summary: Pure markdown documentation skill with no executable code. Contains only templates, principles, and prompts for documenting technical decisions. Zero risk factors detected.

content.value_statement: Technical teams often forget why decisions were made. This skill creates structured Architecture Decision Records that capture context, options considered, and consequences for future reference.
actual_capabilities: Guides users through ADR creation step by step
Provides a complete markdown template for ADRs
Captures constraints, options, pros, and cons
Identifies common documentation mistakes to avoid
Collects decision context through intake questions
limitations: Does not integrate with version control systems
Does not auto-populate from existing code or docs
Does not enforce ADR adoption in your workflow
Does not provide ADR review or approval workflows

use_cases.title: Document Architecture Choices
use_cases.description: Record significant architectural decisions with full context for team reference and compliance.

use_cases.title: Track Technology Decisions
use_cases.description: Maintain a searchable history of technology choices and their business justifications.

use_cases.title: Onboard with Decision Context
use_cases.description: Help new team members understand why the codebase is structured the way it is.

prompt_templates.title: Quick ADR
prompt_templates.prompt: Create an ADR for deciding between PostgreSQL and MongoDB for our user profile storage. Constraints: need ACID compliance, team knows SQL, budget is limited.

prompt_templates.title: Architecture Change
prompt_templates.prompt: Document the decision to migrate from monolithic to microservices architecture. Include risks and reversibility assessment.

prompt_templates.title: Third-Party Service
prompt_templates.prompt: Create an ADR for choosing a payment processor. Compare Stripe, PayPal, and Adyen. Consider fees, integration effort, and compliance.

prompt_templates.title: Pattern Adoption
prompt_templates.prompt: Document the decision to adopt Event Sourcing for the order management system. Explain why this pattern fits better than traditional CRUD.

output_examples.input: Create an ADR for choosing our primary language between Go and Python for our new API service.
output: ADR-001: Go vs Python for API Service
Status: Accepted | Date: 2024-01-15 | Deciders: Engineering Team
Context: Building new REST API for real-time data processing
Constraints: Performance critical, 3-month timeline, existing Go experience
Options: Go (compiled, fast), Python (faster dev), Node.js (not evaluated)
Decision: Go - chosen for performance and concurrency support
Consequences: Positive - 40% latency reduction | Negative - slower initial development | Reversibility: Moderate

best_practices: List at least two real options, even if one is doing nothing
Document the reasoning, not just the conclusion
Match deliberation time to decision reversibility
Include all stakeholders in the decision review process
Create a new ADR to supersede old ones instead of editing them
anti_patterns: Spending more time on reversible decisions than irreversible ones
Making decisions that affect teams without involving them
Editing old ADRs instead of creating new superseding documents

faq.question: What tools work with ADR files?
faq.answer: Any markdown editor supports ADR files. GitHub, GitLab, and VS Code render them natively.

faq.question: How long should an ADR take to write?
faq.description: Simple decisions take 15-30 minutes. Complex architectural choices may require several hours of research.

faq.question: Where should ADRs be stored?
faq.answer: Store ADRs in your repository docs folder alongside architecture diagrams and design documents.

faq.question: Is my data safe?
faq.answer: ADRs contain only text you provide. No data is sent anywhere or stored by this skill.

faq.question: Why not just use commit messages?
faq.answer: Commit messages capture what changed. ADRs capture why decisions were made with full context.

faq.question: How does this compare to RFCs?
faq.answer: ADRs document decisions after they are made. RFCs propose decisions for review. They work well together.
